title: How to Derive the Formula for Kinetic Energy

steps.title: Begin with the Work-Energy Theorem.
steps.content: Begin with the Work-Energy Theorem. The work that is done on an object is related to the change in its kinetic energy. Δ K = W {\displaystyle \Delta K=W}

steps.title: Rewrite work as an integral.
steps.content: Rewrite work as an integral. The end goal is to rewrite the integral in terms of a velocity differential. Δ K = ∫ F ⋅ d r {\displaystyle \Delta K=\int \mathbf {F} \cdot \mathrm {d} \mathbf {r} }

steps.title: Rewrite force in terms of velocity.
steps.content: Rewrite force in terms of velocity. Note that mass is a scalar and can therefore be factored out. Δ K = ∫ m a ⋅ d r = m ∫ d v d t ⋅ d r {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\Delta K&=\int m\mathbf {a} \cdot \mathrm {d} \mathbf {r} \\&=m\int {\frac {\mathrm {d} \mathbf {v} }{\mathrm {d} t}}\cdot \mathrm {d} \mathbf {r} \end{aligned}}}

steps.title: Rewrite the integral in terms of a velocity differential.
steps.content: Rewrite the integral in terms of a velocity differential. Here, it is trivial, because dot products commute. Recall the definition of velocity as well. Δ K = m ∫ d r d t ⋅ d v = m ∫ v ⋅ d v {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\Delta K&=m\int {\frac {\mathrm {d} \mathbf {r} }{\mathrm {d} t}}\cdot \mathrm {d} \mathbf {v} \\&=m\int \mathbf {v} \cdot \mathrm {d} \mathbf {v} \end{aligned}}}

steps.title: Integrate over change in velocity.
steps.content: Integrate over change in velocity. Typically, initial velocity v 0 {\displaystyle v_{0}} is set to 0. Δ K = 1 2 m v 2 − 1 2 m v 0 2 = 1 2 m v 2 {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\Delta K&={\frac {1}{2}}mv^{2}-{\frac {1}{2}}mv_{0}^{2}\\&={\frac {1}{2}}mv^{2}\end{aligned}}}

steps.title: Begin with the Work-Energy Theorem.
steps.content: Begin with the Work-Energy Theorem. The work that is done on an object is related to the change in its kinetic energy. Δ K = W {\displaystyle \Delta K=W}

steps.title: Rewrite work in terms of acceleration.
steps.content: Rewrite work in terms of acceleration. Note that using algebra alone in this derivation restricts us to constant acceleration. Δ K = F Δ x = m a Δ x {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\Delta K&=F\Delta x\\&=ma\Delta x\end{aligned}}} Here, Δ x {\displaystyle \Delta x} is the displacement.

steps.title: Relate velocity, acceleration, and displacement.
steps.content: Relate velocity, acceleration, and displacement. There are several constant acceleration kinematic equations that relate time, displacement, velocity, and acceleration. The "timeless" equation which does not contain time is below. v 2 = v 0 2 + 2 a Δ x {\displaystyle v^{2}=v_{0}^{2}+2a\Delta x} When an object starts from rest, v 0 = 0. {\displaystyle v_{0}=0.}

steps.title: Solve for acceleration.
steps.content: Solve for acceleration. Remember, initial velocity is 0. a = v 2 2 Δ x {\displaystyle a={\frac {v^{2}}{2\Delta x}}}

steps.title: Substitute acceleration into the original equation and simplify.
steps.content: Substitute acceleration into the original equation and simplify. Δ K = m ( v 2 2 Δ x ) Δ x = 1 2 m v 2 {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\Delta K&=m\left({\frac {v^{2}}{2\Delta x}}\right)\Delta x\\&={\frac {1}{2}}mv^{2}\end{aligned}}}
